swamp.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: land that is always very wet or covered with a layer of water
swamp.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to suddenly give someone a lot of work, problems etc to deal with
swamp.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Weâ€™ve been swamped with phone calls since the advert appeared.
swamp.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to go somewhere or surround something in large numbers, especially in a short period of time
swamp.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: In the summer the village is swamped by visitors.
swamp.translation[1].definitions[1].note: Swamp is usually passive in meanings 1 and 2
swamp.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to suddenly cover an area with a lot of water
swamp.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to suddenly give someone a lot of work or things to deal with
swamp.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The flood of orders swamped some understaffed trading desks.
Brokers said they were swamped with calls after the announcement.
swamp.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: if goods or manufacturers swamp an economy, market etc, there are so many of them available that the price of goods becomes very low
swamp.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Cheap imports still swamp U.S. sales in electronic appliances.
The moment they see a chance to make money, mining companiesswamp the market with new shares.
